Semiconductors

Intrinsic Semiconductors

  • Covalent bond: each pair of shared electrons.
  • Free electrons: thermal energy breaks some of the covalent bonds and free some electrons.
  • Holes: positively charged carriers that attracts an electron

The concentration of free electrons is denoted nnn, and the concentration of holes is denoted ppp.

Recombination is the process free electrons fill the holes. Thermal generation is the process that as temperature increases, more covalent bonds are broken and electron-hole pairs are generated.

In thermal equilibrium, the recombination rate is equal to the generation rate, and we have n=pn=pn=p.

Doped Semiconductors

Type Valence Called Majority Charge Carrior
nnn type 5 donor Free Electrons
ppp type 3 acceptor Holes

PN Junction

Carrier-Depletion Region exist on both sides of the junction, with nnn side of of this region positively charged and ppp side negatively charged.

The charges on both sides of the depletion region cause an electric field EEE to be established across the region. Hence a potential difference results across the depletion region, with nnn side at a positive voltage relative to the ppp side. This voltage drop acts as a barrier that has to be overcome for holes to diffuse into the nnn region adn electrons to diffuse into the ppp region. This voltage V0V_0V0​ is called junction built-in voltage, for typical diodes, V0=0.7V_0=0.7V0​=0.7.

Note that when pnpnpn junction terminals are open, the voltage measured between the terminals will be zero. In other words, the voltage V0V_0V0​ across the depletion region does not appear between the junction terminals. This is because of the contact voltages existing at the metal semiconductor junctions at the terminals.which counter and exactly balance the barrier voltage.

PN junction with applied voltage:

Saturation Current IsI_sIs​: in the reverse direction, the current saturates at −Is-I_s−Is​. IsI_sIs​ is directly proportional to the cross-sectional area AAA of the junction.

The I-V characteristics of the PN junction:

Observe that as VVV reaches the value VZV_ZVZ​ , the dramatic increase in reverse current is accompanied by a very small increase in the reverse voltage; that is, the reverse voltage across the junction remains very close to the value VZ. The phenomenon that occurs at is known as junction breakdown. It is not a destructive phenomenon. That is, the pn junction can be repeatedly operated in the breakdown region without a permanent effect on its characteristics.

Diodes

Ideal Diode

If a negative voltage is applied to the diode, no current flows and the diode behaves as an open circuit. Diodes operated in this mode are said to be reverse biased, or operated in the reverse direction. An ideal diode has zero current when operated in the reverse direction and is said to be cut off, or simply off.

On the other hand, if a positive current is applied to the ideal diode, zero voltage drop appears across the diode. In other words, the ideal diode behaves as a short circuit in the forward direction; it passes any current with zero voltage drop. A forward-biased diode is said to be turned on, or simply on.

  • Anode: positive terminal
  • Cathode: negative terminal

Nonideal Diode Model

In the forward-bias region,

i=Is(ev/VT−1)i=I_s(e^{v/V_T}-1) i=Is​(ev/VT​−1)

  • Where IsI_sIs​ is a constant for a given diode at a given temperature called saturation current.
  • VTV_TVT​ is a constant called the thermal voltage VT=kTq\displaystyle V_T=\frac{kT}{q}VT​=qkT​.
  • For the reverse-bias region, i≈−Isi\approx -I_si≈−Is​.

The voltage drop across a non-ideal diode is piecewise (v>0.7Vv>0.7 Vv>0.7V and v≤0.7Vv\le 0.7 Vv≤0.7V).

  • v≤0.7Vv\le 0.7 Vv≤0.7V means the diode is off
  • v>0.7Vv>0.7 Vv>0.7V means the diode is on, and therefore it could be treated as a 0.7V0.7 V0.7V voltage source (for the voltage drop).
  • The resistance across the diode rDr_DrD​ is negligible.

Clamped Capacitor

Consider the basic peak-rectifier circuit, if the output is taken across the diode instead of the capacitor, we have a clamp circuit!

The output of the circuit (voltage across the diode) is given by

vO=vI+vCv_O=v_I+v_C vO​=vI​+vC​

where vCv_CvC​ is constant.

The output waveform will have its lowest peak clamped to 0 V, which is why the circuit is called a clamped capacitor. It should be obvious that reversing the diode polarity will provide an output waveform whose highest peak is clamped to 0 V.

Limiter and Voltage Regulator

Limiter Circuits:

A voltage regulator is a circuit whose purpose is to provide a constant dc voltage between its output terminals. The output voltage is requried to remain as constant possible in spite of changes in load current drawn from the regulator output terminal and changes in the dc power-supply voltage that feeds the regulator circuit.

MOS Field-Effect Transistors

Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor Field-Effect Transistor (MOSFET) has

  • 2 heavily n-doped regions: Source and Drain
  • Gate electrode: metal deposited on top of the silicon-oxide layer
  • Body: metal contacts made to the p-substrate region

The four terminals:

  • Gate Terminal GGG
  • Source Terminal SSS (generally kept grounded)
  • Drain Terminal DDD
  • Body Terminal BBB

MOSFET Operations

With zero voltage applied to the gate, two back-to-back diodes exist in series between drain and source. There is very high resistance in the path between drain and source.

When there is a positive voltage applied to gate, the gate voltage attracts free electrons from source and drain nnn regions into the channel region. When a sufficient number of electrons accumulate near the surface of the substrate under the gate, an n region is in effect created in the p-substrate, connecting the source and drain regions, Now if a voltage is applied between drain and source, current flows through this induced n region, carried by the mobile electrons. The induced n-region thus forms a channel for current flow from drain to source. Correspondingly, the NPN MOSFET is calle an n-channel MOSFET aka NMOS transistor.

The value of vGSv_{GS}vGS​ at which a sufficient number of mobile electrons accumulate in the channel region to form a conducting channel is called the threshold voltage VtV_tVt​.

Fun fact: why is MOSFET called MOSFET? The gate and channel region form a parallel-plate capacitor, with the oxide layer acting as a capacitor dielectric. The electric field across the capacitor controls the channel conductivity. This is the origin of the name "field-effect transistor".

Overdrive voltage vOVv_{OV}vOV​ is the excess of vGSv_{GS}vGS​ over ttt.

When we keep vDSv_{DS}vDS​ small, vDS≪2VOVv_{DS}\ll 2V_{OV}vDS​≪2VOV​ under vGS>Vtv_{GS}>V_tvGS​>Vt​:

When we increase vDSv_{DS}vDS​ with vGS>Vtv_{GS}>V_tvGS​>Vt​ (triode region):

When vDS≥VOVv_{DS}\ge V_{OV}vDS​≥VOV​ (saturation region):

Continue to increase vDSv_{DS}vDS​ beyond vDS∣satv_{DS}|_{sat}vDS​∣sat​ causes the channel pinch-off point to move slightly away from the drain, thus reducing the effective channel length. This phenomenon is known as channel-length modulation, a term that will frequently appear later on. It's effect can be accounted for via λ\lambdaλ mentioned in the next section. Don't worry about it.

Note that in this case, we have a gate-to-source capacitor.

MOSFET DC Circuit Analysis

The general analysis procedure for DC MOSFET circuits is:

  1. Decide which region the MOSFET operates (saturation or triode). If it is not immediately obvious, assume its saturation and test its validity later.
  2. Use the drain current IDI_DID​ to find the unknowns.

Diode-connected transistor:

CMOS Inverter primer:

MOSFET Amplifiers, Intuition

Region MOSFET Function vGSv_{GS}vGS​ Controls
Triode Voltage-Controlled Resistor Resistance rDSr_{DS}rDS​ (linear)
Saturation Voltage-Controlled Current Source Drain current iDi_DiD​ (nonlinear )

A voltage-controlled current source can serve as a transconductance amplifier (voltage in, current out).

A Voltage Transfer Characteristic (VTC) is simply a plot of the output voltage versus input voltage.

We now implement a voltage amplifier with MOSFET.

Let vGSv_{GS}vGS​ be the input voltage, we use a load resistance RDR_DRD​ to convert the drain current to a voltage. We pick the output voltage vDSv_{DS}vDS​ between the drain and ground, rather than simply across RDR_DRD​ because of the need to maintain a ground reference throughout the circuit.

vDS=VDD−iDRD(2.1)v_{DS}=V_{DD}-i_DR_D \tag{2.1} vDS​=VDD​−iD​RD​(2.1)

Note that vDSv_{DS}vDS​ is an inverted version (minus sign) of iDRDi_D R_DiD​RD​ that is shifted by a constant value of the supply voltage VDDV_{DD}VDD​

We bias the voltage amplifier configuration to obtain linear amplification. Point QQQ is known as a bias point or dc operating point.

The gain could be determined by the slope at the bias point QQQ:

Av≡dvDSdvGS∣vGS=VGS=−knVOVRDA_v\equiv \left.\frac{dv_{DS}}{dv_{GS}}\right|_{v_{GS}=V_{GS}} = -k_n V_{OV} R_D Av​≡dvGS​dvDS​​∣∣∣∣​vGS​=VGS​​=−kn​VOV​RD​

Observe that:

  • Gain is negative, the voltage amplifier is inverting.
  • The gain is proportional to the load resistance RDR_DRD​, transconductance parameter knk_nkn​, overdrive voltage VOVV_{OV}VOV​.

Just for completeness's sake, we derive the small signal voltage gain formula, (see the small signal op. section).

vDS=VDD−RDiD=VDD−RD(ID+id)=VDS−RDid\begin{aligned} v_{DS}&=V_{DD}-R_D i_D\\ &=V_{DD}-R_D (I_D + i_d)\\ &=V_{DS} - R_D i_d \end{aligned} vDS​​=VDD​−RD​iD​=VDD​−RD​(ID​+id​)=VDS​−RD​id​​

The small-signal component of the drain voltage is

vds=−idRD=−gmvgsRDv_{ds}=-i_d R_D=-g_m v_{gs}R_D vds​=−id​RD​=−gm​vgs​RD​

Voltage gain is therefore

Av≡vdsvgs=−gmRDA_v\equiv \frac{v_{ds}}{v_{gs}}=-g_mR_D Av​≡vgs​vds​​=−gm​RD​

Determining the VTC by Graphical Analysis

From equation (2.1)(2.1)(2.1), we derive

iD=VDDRD−1RDvDSi_D=\frac{V_{DD}}{R_D}-\frac{1}{R_D} v_{DS} iD​=RD​VDD​​−RD​1​vDS​

This straight line on iDi_DiD​ vs vDSv_{DS}vDS​, intersects the horizontal axis at vDS=VDDv_{DS}=V_{DD}vDS​=VDD​, called load line.

Note that:

Point vGSv_{GS}vGS​
A vGS=Vtv_{GS}=V_tvGS​=Vt​
B leave saturation, enter triode
C vGS=VDDv_{GS}=V_{DD}vGS​=VDD​
Q vGS=VGS,vDS=VDSv_{GS}=V_{GS}, v_{DS}=V_{DS}vGS​=VGS​,vDS​=VDS​

If the MOSFET is to be used as a switch, then at AAA the transistor is off (open switch), at CCC the transistor operates as a closed switch (low-valued resistor rDSr_DSrD​S).

It is important to pick the bias point QQQ with VDSV_{DS}VDS​ in between VDDV_{DD}VDD​ and the boundary of the triode region. VDSV_{DS}VDS​ too close to VDDV_{DD}VDD​ means not enough room for positive signal swing. VDSV_{DS}VDS​ too close to the boundary of the triode region means not enough room for negative signal swing.

Biasing in MOSFET Amplifier

Biasing by Fixing VGSV_{GS}VGS​

The most straightforward aproach to biasing a MOSFET is to fix its gate-to-source voltage VGSV_{GS}VGS​ to the value required to provide the desired IDI_DID​.

This is a poor technique because consider two iDi_DiD​-vGSv_{GS}vGS​ characteristic curves representign extreme values in a batch of MOSFETS of the same type. Observe that for the fixed value of VGSV_{GS}VGS​, the resultant spread in the values of the drain current can be substantial:

Biasing by Fixing VGV_GVG​ and Connect Resistance to Source

An excellent biasing technique for discrete MOSFET circuits consists of fixing the dc voltage at the gate, VGV_GVG​, and connecting a resistance in the source lead. We have

VG=VGS+RSIDV_G = V_{GS}+R_S I_D VG​=VGS​+RS​ID​

RSR_SRS​ provides negative feedback which stabilize the value of IDI_DID​. When IDI_DID​ increases, VGSV_{GS}VGS​ must decrease since VGV_GVG​ is constant. This in turn results in a decrease in IDI_DID​. RSR_SRS​ is therefore called degeneration resistance.

Biasing using a Drain-to-Gate Feedback Resistor

Here the large feedback resistance RGR_GRG​ (usually in the megohm range) forces the dc voltage at the gate to be equal to that at the drain (because IG=0I_G = 0IG​=0). Thus we can write

VGS=VDS=VDD−RDIDV_{GS}=V_{DS}=V_{DD}-R_D I_D VGS​=VDS​=VDD​−RD​ID​

which can be rewritten in the form VDD=VGS+RDIDV_{DD}=V_{GS}+R_D I_DVDD​=VGS​+RD​ID​ that is identical to the form VG=VGS+RSIDV_G = V_{GS}+R_S I_DVG​=VGS​+RS​ID​ discussed in the last section. Thus, if IDI_DID​ for some reason increases, VGSV_{GS}VGS​ must decrease. As a result, the negative feedback keeps the value of IDI_DID​ as constant as possible.

Notes to myself: the reason we must have a very large RGR_GRG​ instead of a short circuit to keep VGS=VDSV_{GS}=V_{DS}VGS​=VDS​ is because we want the circuit to work under AC too.

Biasing using Constant-Current Source

The most effective scheme for biasing a MOSFET amplifier is that using a constant-current source.

The heart of the implementation circuit is transistor Q1Q_1Q1​, whose drain is shorted to its gate and thus operating in the saturation region:

ID1=12kn′(WL)1(VGS−Vt)2I_{D1}=\frac{1}{2}k_n'\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_1(V_{GS}- V_t)^2 ID1​=21​kn′​(LW​)1​(VGS​−Vt​)2

We neglected the channel-length modulation (assume λ=0\lambda=0λ=0),

ID1=IREF=VDD+VSS−VGSRI_{D1}=I_{REF}=\frac{V_{DD}+V_{SS}-V_{GS}}{R} ID1​=IREF​=RVDD​+VSS​−VGS​​

Now we consider transistor Q2Q_2Q2​. It has the same VGSV_{GS}VGS​ as Q1Q_1Q1​. Therefore if we assume it is operating in saturation, the drain current would be

I=ID2=12kn′(WL)2(VGS−Vt)2I=I_{D2}=\frac{1}{2}k_n'\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_2(V_{GS}- V_t)^2 I=ID2​=21​kn′​(LW​)2​(VGS​−Vt​)2

Again, we ignore the channel-length modulation, and we obtain

I=IREF(W/L)2(W/L)1I=I_{REF}\frac{(W/L)_2}{(W/L)_1} I=IREF​(W/L)1​(W/L)2​​

III is related to IREFI_{REF}IREF​ by the ratio of the aspect ratios of Q1Q_1Q1​ and Q2Q_2Q2​. This circuit is known as a current mirror which will be discussed later.

Small-Signal Operation and Models

We generally separate DC analysis and the signal analysis.

DC Analysis and AC Analysis

For DC analysis, we

  • Eliminate small-signal input
  • Open all coupling capacitors (since they block DC currents)

For AC analysis, we

  • Replace DC voltage supply with short-circuit to ground
  • Replace the coupling capacitor with short circuits

Small-Signal Models

Let vgsv_{gs}vgs​ be the small signal to be amplified, let the bias voltage be VGSV_{GS}VGS​. The total instataneous value of vGSv_{GS}vGS​ becomes

vGS(t)=VGS+vgs(t)(2.2)v_{GS}(t)=V_{GS}+v_{gs}(t) \tag{2.2} vGS​(t)=VGS​+vgs​(t)(2.2)

This results in the total instataneous drain current iDi_DiD​:

iD=12kn(VGS+vgs−Vt)2=12kn(VGS−Vt)2+kn(VGS−Vt)vgs+12kn(vgs)2\begin{aligned} i_D&=\frac{1}{2} k_n (V_{GS} +v_{gs} -V_t)^2\\ &=\frac{1}{2} k_n (V_{GS} - V_t)^2 + k_n(V_{GS}-V_t)v_{gs}+\frac{1}{2}k_n (v_{gs})^2 \end{aligned} iD​​=21​kn​(VGS​+vgs​−Vt​)2=21​kn​(VGS​−Vt​)2+kn​(VGS​−Vt​)vgs​+21​kn​(vgs​)2​

The first term on the right-hand side can be recognized as the dc bias current IDI_DID​ (which is obtained by setting small signal components vgsv_{gs}vgs​ to 0). The second term represents a current component that is directly proportional to the input signal vgsv_{gs}vgs​. The third term is highly undesirable because it represents nonlinear distortion. To reduce the effect of this nonlinear distortion, the input signal should be kept small such that

12kn(vgs)2≪kn(VGS−Vt)vgs\frac{1}{2} k_n (v_gs)^2\ll k_n(V_{GS}-V_t) v_{gs} 21​kn​(vg​s)2≪kn​(VGS​−Vt​)vgs​

Equivalently,

vgs≪2VOV(2.3)v_{gs} \ll 2 V_{OV} \tag{2.3} vgs​≪2VOV​(2.3)

Equation (2.3)(2.3)(2.3) is called small-signal condition, if it is satisfied, we may neglect the third term in the iDi_DiD​ equation, and we obtain

iD≈ID+idwhereid=kn(VGS−Vt)vgs(2.4)i_D\approx I_D + i_d \qquad\textrm{where}\quad i_d= k_n(V_{GS}-V_t)v_{gs} \tag{2.4} iD​≈ID​+id​whereid​=kn​(VGS​−Vt​)vgs​(2.4)

The parameter that relates idi_did​ and vgsv_{gs}vgs​ is the MOSFET transconductance gmg_mgm​,

gm≡idvgs=knVOV(2.5)g_m\equiv \frac{i_d}{v_{gs}}=k_n V_{OV} \tag{2.5} gm​≡vgs​id​​=kn​VOV​(2.5)

Now, substitute kn=2ID/(VOV)2k_n=2I_D/(V_{OV})^2kn​=2ID​/(VOV​)2, we arrive at

gm=2IDVOV(2.6)g_m=\frac{2 I_D}{V_{OV}} \tag{2.6} gm​=VOV​2ID​​(2.6)

From the graphical interpretation of the small-signal operation of the MOSFET, we obtain

gm≡∂iD∂vGS∣vGS=VGSg_m\equiv \left.\frac{\partial i_D}{\partial v_{GS}}\right|_{v_{GS}=V_{GS}} gm​≡∂vGS​∂iD​​∣∣∣∣​vGS​=VGS​​

Since we have id=gmvgsi_d=g_m v_{gs}id​=gm​vgs​, we have the small-signal equivalent circuit model

The most serious issue of the first small-signal model is it assumes the drain current in saturation is independent of the drain voltage. The second model takes channel-length modulation into account (i.e. λ≠0\lambda\neq 0λ​=0), with

ro=∣VA∣IDr_o=\frac{|V_A|}{I_D} ro​=ID​∣VA​∣​

  • IDI_DID​ is the drain current without taking channel length modulation into account.
  • 1/ro1/r_o1/ro​ is the slope of the iDi_DiD​ vs vDSv_{DS}vDS​ graph in the saturation region.

Replacing the MOSFET with the small-signal model, we have

Av=vdsvgs=−gm(RD∥ro)A_v=\frac{v_{ds}}{v_{gs}}=-g_m(R_D\parallel r_o) Av​=vgs​vds​​=−gm​(RD​∥ro​)

Summary of small-signal equivalent circuit models:

Don't worry about the names of the model, they just sound cool.

ro=ΔvDSΔiD=∂vDS∂iDr_o=\frac{\Delta v_{DS}}{\Delta i_D} =\frac{\partial v_{DS}}{\partial i_D} ro​=ΔiD​ΔvDS​​=∂iD​∂vDS​​

id=gmvgs+vdsro(2.8)i_d=g_m v_{gs} + \frac{v_{ds}}{r_o} \tag{2.8} id​=gm​vgs​+ro​vds​​(2.8)

Complementary MOS (CMOS)

The Body Effect*

In many applications the source terminal is connected to the body (substrate) terminal BBB, which results in the pnpnpn junction between the substrate and the induced channel having a zero bias. In such a case the substrate does not play any role in circuit operation adn its existence can be ignored altogether.

In integrated circuits, however, to maintain the cutoff condition for all the substrate-to-channel junctions (such that body-source would maintain a reverse bias or no bias):

  • NMOS substrate is usually connected to the negative power supply.
  • PMOS substrate is usually connected to the positive power supply.

The reverse-bias voltage between source and body will have an effect on device operation. The effect of VSBV_{SB}VSB​ on the channel can be conveniently represented as a change in the threshold voltage VtV_tVt​. This is known as the body effect.

Vt=Vt0+γ[2ϕf+VSB−2ϕf]V_t= V_{t0}+\gamma \left[ \sqrt{2\phi_f+V_{SB}} - \sqrt{2\phi_f} \right] Vt​=Vt0​+γ[2ϕf​+VSB​​−2ϕf​​]

where vt0v_{t0}vt0​ is the threshold voltage when VSB=0V_{SB}=0VSB​=0; ϕf\phi_fϕf​ is a physical parameter with 2ϕf2\phi_f2ϕf​ typically 0.6 V0.6\ \textrm{V}0.6 V; γ\gammaγ is a fabrication-process parameter aka body-effect parameter given by 2qNAεs/Cox\sqrt{2q N_A\varepsilon_s}/C_{ox}2qNA​εs​​/Cox​, don't worry about it.

The substrate is always connected to the power supply, and acts as a signal ground. A signal voltage vbsv_{bs}vbs​ develops between the body (B) and source (S). The substrate then acts as a "second gate" or a backgate for the MOSFET. Therefore, the signal vsbv_{sb}vsb​ gives rise to a drain-current componenet gmbvbsg_{mb} v_{bs}gmb​vbs​, where gmbg_{mb}gmb​ is the body transconductance

gmb≡∂iD∂vBS∣vGS=constant, vDS=constantg_{mb}\equiv \left. \frac{\partial i_D}{\partial v_{BS}}\right|_{v_{GS}=\textrm{constant},\ v_{DS}=\textrm{constant}} gmb​≡∂vBS​∂iD​​∣∣∣∣​vGS​=constant, vDS​=constant​

gmb=χgmg_mb=\chi g_m gm​b=χgm​

χ≡∂Vt∂VSB=γ22ϕf+VSB\chi\equiv \frac{\partial V_t}{\partial V_{SB}}=\frac{\gamma}{2\sqrt{2\phi_f + V_{SB}}} χ≡∂VSB​∂Vt​​=22ϕf​+VSB​​γ​

Three Basic MOSFET Amplifier Configurations

There are three basic configurations for MOSFET amplifier. Each of these configurations has one its three terminals grounded, thus creating a two-port network with the grounded terminal being common to the input and output ports.

  • Common-Source (CS)
  • Common-Gate (CG)
  • Common-Drain (CD) AKA source follower

We start with unilateral amplifiers (that do not contain internal feedback).

If you wonder why RDR_DRD​ is shorted to ground and not connected to the power supply, note that this is AC model (refer back to AC analysis).

Common-Source Amplifier

RDR_DRD​ is the drain resistance, since the output voltage signal vov_ovo​ is take between the drain and th ground, across RDR_DRD​.

We analyze its characteristic parameters input resistance RinR_{in}Rin​, open-loop voltage gain AoA_oAo​, and output resistance RoR_oRo​:

Rin=∞R_{in}=\infty Rin​=∞

vo=−(gmvgs)(RD∥ro)v_o=-(g_m v_{gs})(R_D\parallel r_o) vo​=−(gm​vgs​)(RD​∥ro​)

Ao=−gm(RD∥ro)≈−gmRDA_o=-g_m (R_D\parallel r_o)\approx-g_m R_D Ao​=−gm​(RD​∥ro​)≈−gm​RD​

To obtain the output resistance, we set viv_ivi​ (vgsv_{gs}vgs​) to zero, and obtain

Ro=RD∥ro≈RDR_o = R_D\parallel r_o \approx R_D Ro​=RD​∥ro​≈RD​

The overall voltage gain with load resistance is

Gv=−gm(RD∥RL∥ro)G_v=- g_m (R_D\parallel R_L \parallel r_o) Gv​=−gm​(RD​∥RL​∥ro​)

Common-Gate Amplifier

Note that we have not included ror_oro​ which would have complicated the analysis considerably.

Rin=1gmR_{in} = \frac{1}{g_m} Rin​=gm​1​

vo=−iRD,i=−vi1/gm(source current)v_o=-i R_{D}, \qquad i=-\frac{v_i}{1/g_m}\quad\textrm{(source current)} vo​=−iRD​,i=−1/gm​vi​​(source current)

Ao≡vovi=gmRDA_o\equiv \frac{v_o}{v_i}=g_m R_D Ao​≡vi​vo​​=gm​RD​

Ro=RD(by inspection)R_o=R_D\quad\textrm{(by inspection)} Ro​=RD​(by inspection)

The overall voltage gain with load resistance is

Gv=1/gmRsig+1/gm[gm(RD∥RL)]=(RD∥RL)Rsig+1/gmG_v=\frac{1/g_m}{R_{sig}+1/g_m}[g_m(R_D\parallel R_L)]=\frac{(R_D\parallel R_L)}{R_{sig} + 1/g_m} Gv​=Rsig​+1/gm​1/gm​​[gm​(RD​∥RL​)]=Rsig​+1/gm​(RD​∥RL​)​

Observe that the overall voltage gain is simply the ratio of the total resistance in the drain circuit to the total resistance in the source circuit.

Note that the low input resistance of CG amplifier can cause severe attenuation of input signal. Because of its low input resistance, the CG amplifier alone has very limited application.

Common-Drain Amplifier

Rin=∞R_{in} = \infty Rin​=∞

Av≡vovi=RLRL+1/gmA_v\equiv \frac{v_o}{v_i}=\frac{R_L}{R_L+1/g_m} Av​≡vi​vo​​=RL​+1/gm​RL​​

The open-circuit gain is unity!

(Av)o=lim⁡RL→∞Av=1(A_v)_o = \lim_{R_L\rightarrow \infty} A_v = 1 (Av​)o​=RL​→∞lim​Av​=1

The output resistance RoR_oRo​ is found by setting vi=0v_i=0vi​=0, now looking back into the output terminal, excluding RLR_LRL​, we see 1/gm1/g_m1/gm​, therefore

Ro=1/gmR_o=1/g_m Ro​=1/gm​

The voltage at the source terminal will follow that at the input, hence the name source follower.

MOSFET Amplifier Summary

  • CS configuration is best suited for realizing the bulk of gain required in an amplifier.
  • Including a resistor RsR_sRs​ in the source lead of the CS stage provides a number of performance improvements at the expense of gain reduction.
  • CG is useful as high-frequency amplifier studied later.
  • CD (source follower) is usually used as voltage buffer for connecting a high-resistance source to a low-resistance load.

Practical MOSFET Amplifier Circuits*

We first consider the common-source amplifier circuit:

Observe that to establish a signal ground or an ac ground at the source, we connect a large capacitor CsC_sCs​ between the source and the ground to provide a mery small impedance. In this way, the signal current passes through CSC_SCS​ to ground and thus bypasses the output resistance of the current source III. Hence, CSC_SCS​ is called a bypass capacitor. THe lower the signal frequency, the less effective the bypass capacitor becomes. For our purposes here we shall assume CSC_SCS​ is acting as a perfect short circuit and thus is establishing a zero signal voltage at the MOSFET source.

In order not to disturb the dc bios current and voltages, the signal to be amplified, shown as voltage source vsigv_{sig}vsig​ with an internal resistance RsigR_{sig}Rsig​, is connected to the gate through a large capacitor CC1C_{C1}CC1​, Capacitor CC1C_{C1}CC1​, known as a coupling capacitor is required to act as a perfect short circuit at all signal frequencies of interest while blocking dc. Note that as the signal frequency is lowered,the impedance of CC1C_{C1}CC1​ will increase and its effectiveness as a coupling capacitor will be correspondingly reduced.

We observe that input resistance is no longer infinite:

Rin=RGR_{in}=R_G Rin​=RG​

We then consider the common-gate amplifier:

Lastly, we consider the source follower:

As a general rule, in designing IC MOS circuits, one should strive to realize as many of the functions required as possible using MOS transistors only and, when needed, small MOS capacitors.

Basic Gain Cell

The basic gain cell in an IC amplifier is a common-source (CS) or common-emitter (CE) transistor loaded with a constant-current source.

Note that we have replaced the drain resistance RDR_DRD​ with constant-current sources. This is done for 2 reasons:

  1. It is difficult in IC technology to implement resistances with reasonably precise values; rather, it is much easier to use current sources.
  2. By using a constant current source we are effectively operating CS and CE amplifiers with very high (ideally infinite) load resistance. We therefore obtain a much higher gain than if a finite RDR_DRD​ is used.

These circuits are said to be current-source loaded or active loaded.

We perform small signal analysis for the active-load CS amplifier:

{Rin=∞(Av)o=−gmroRo=ro\begin{cases} R_{in} = \infty\\ (A_v)_o = -g_m r_o\\ R_o = r_o \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​Rin​=∞(Av​)o​=−gm​ro​Ro​=ro​​

Both sircuits realize a voltage gain of magnitude gmrog_m r_ogm​ro​. Since this is the maximum gain obtainable in a CS or CE amplifier, we refer to it as the intrisic gain and give it the symbol A0A_0A0​.

Intrinsic Gain

We derive a formula for the intrinsic gain (Av)0=gmro(A_v)_0 = g_m r_o(Av​)0​=gm​ro​ for BJT by recalling

{gm=IC/VTro=VA/IC→A0=gmro=VAVT\begin{cases} g_m=I_C/V_T\\ r_o=V_A/I_C \end{cases} \qquad\rightarrow\qquad A_0=g_m r_o = \frac{V_A}{V_T} {gm​=IC​/VT​ro​=VA​/IC​​→A0​=gm​ro​=VT​VA​​

Thus A0A_0A0​ is simply the ratio of Early Voltage VAV_AVA​ and thermal voltage VTV_TVT​ (NOT threshold voltage!) The value of A0A_0A0​ will be in the range of 200 to 5k.

For MOSFET,

{gm=IDVOV/2=2μnCox(W/L)IDro=VA/ID=(VA′L)/ID→A0=2VA′LVOV=VA′2(μnCox)(WL)ID\begin{cases} \displaystyle g_m= \frac{I_D}{V_{OV}/2}=\sqrt{2\mu_n C_{ox}(W/L)} \sqrt{I_D}\\ r_o=V_A/I_D=(V_A' L)/I_D \end{cases} \quad\rightarrow\quad A_0=\frac{2V_A'L}{V_{OV}}=\frac{V_A'\sqrt{2(\mu_n C_{ox})(WL)}}{\sqrt{I_D}} ⎩⎨⎧​gm​=VOV​/2ID​​=2μn​Cox​(W/L)​ID​​ro​=VA​/ID​=(VA′​L)/ID​​→A0​=VOV​2VA′​L​=ID​​VA′​2(μn​Cox​)(WL)​​

where VAV_AVA​ is the Early voltage and VA′V'_AVA′​ is the technology-dependent component of Early Voltage. We note that for a given technology (given value of VA′V_A'VA′​),

  • The intrinsic gain A0A_0A0​ can be increased by using a longer MOSFET and operating it at lower VOVV_{OV}VOV​. The trade off is the decreasing amplifier bandwidth which will be discussed much later.
  • The intrinsic gain is inversely proportional to the drain current IDI_DID​. At very low IDI_DID​, the MOSFET enters the subthreshold region of operation and has constant intrinsic gain. Note that Lowering IDI_DID​ has trade off:
    • Lower gmg_mgm​.
    • Less ability to drive capacitive loads (decrease in bandwidth).

Cascode Amplifier

Current Buffer

How can we increase the voltage gain obtained from the basic gain cell? We increase the output resistance of both the amplifying transistor and the current-source load. That is, we seek a circuit, known as the current buffer that passes the current gmvig_m v_igm​vi​ provided by the amplifying transistor right through, but increases the resistance from ror_oro​ to a much larger value.

Note that it is not sufficient to raise the output resistance of the amplifying transistor only. We also need to raise the output resistance of the current-source load. We may use another current buffer to do so.

Current buffer is the dual of voltage buffer (the source follower), which passes the voltage but lowers the resistance level.

Recall that CG circuit have unity current gain. We now investigate it's resistance transformation property.

Cascoding

Cascoding refers to the use of common-gate configuration to provide current buffering for the output of a common-source amplifying transistor.

Our goal is to determine the overall transconductance GmG_mGm​ and output resistance ROR_ORO​. We first replace Q1,Q2Q_1, Q_2Q1​,Q2​ in the circuit above with their small-signal equivalent circuit, which we analyze to determine ioi_oio​ in terms of viv_ivi​.

Nodal at (d1,s2)(d_1, s_2)(d1​,s2​) (with voltage −vgs2-v_{gs2}−vgs2​):

gm2vgs2+vgs2ro1+vgs2ro2=gm1vig_{m2} v_{gs2} + \frac{v_{gs2}}{r_{o1}} + \frac{v_{gs2}}{r_{o2}} =g_{m1} v_i gm2​vgs2​+ro1​vgs2​​+ro2​vgs2​​=gm1​vi​

gm2vgs2≈gm1vi∵gm2≫1/ro1,1/ro2g_{m2} v_{gs2}\approx g_{m1} v_i \qquad \because g_{m2}\gg 1/r_{o1}, 1/r_{o2} gm2​vgs2​≈gm1​vi​∵gm2​≫1/ro1​,1/ro2​

The output current ioi_oio​ at Q2Q_2Q2​ is

io=(gm2+1ro2)vgs2≈gm2vgs2i_o=\left(g_{m2}+\frac{1}{r_{o2}}\right) v_{gs2}\approx g_{m2} v_{gs2} io​=(gm2​+ro2​1​)vgs2​≈gm2​vgs2​

Gm=iovi=gm1G_m = \frac{i_o}{v_i} = g_{m1} Gm​=vi​io​​=gm1​

Which is what we want.

Now, since RsR_sRs​ of Q2Q_2Q2​ is ro1r_{o1}ro1​, the output resistance RoR_oRo​ is given by

Ro≈(gm2 ro2)ro1R_o\approx (g_{m2}\ r_{o2}) r_{o1} Ro​≈(gm2​ ro2​)ro1​

Now we compute the open circuit gain of the cascode amplifier:

Avo=−(gm1 ro1)(gm2 ro2)A_{vo} = -(g_{m1}\ r_{o1})(g_{m2}\ r_{o2}) Avo​=−(gm1​ ro1​)(gm2​ ro2​)

Implementing High-Resistance Current Source

If the current source load is implemented with a PMOS transistor (which can be part of a PMOS current mirror), there will be dire consequences:

Av=−gm1[(gm2ro2ro1)∥ro3]≈−gm1ro3A_v = -g_{m1}[(g_{m2} r_{o2} r_{o1}) \parallel r_{o3} ] \approx -g_{m1} r_{o3} Av​=−gm1​[(gm2​ro2​ro1​)∥ro3​]≈−gm1​ro3​

Totally wasted!

The solution to this issue is to use a cascode current source (LOL!):

Now, if all transistors match,

Av=−gm1{[(gm2ro2)ro1]∥[(gm3ro3)ro4]}≈−12A02A_v = -g_{m1} \{[(g_{m2}r_{o2}) r_{o1}] \parallel [(g_{m3} r_{o3}) r_{o4}]\} \approx -\frac{1}{2} A_0^2 Av​=−gm1​{[(gm2​ro2​)ro1​]∥[(gm3​ro3​)ro4​]}≈−21​A02​

Differential Amplifier

The figure below shows the basic MOS differential-pair configuration. Although each drain is shown connected to the positive supply through a resistance RDR_DRD​, in most cases active loads are employed. Whatever type of load is used, it is essential that the MOSFETs are not in the triode region of operation.

  • VCMV_{CM}VCM​ is the common-mode voltage (the voltage shared by both terminals)
  • Input common-mode range is an important spec of a diff amp. This is the range of VCMV_{CM}VCM​ over which the differentail pair operates properly.
  • Differential pair responds to difference-mode or differential input signals vidv_{id}vid​.
    • With vidv_{id}vid​ positive: vGS1>vGS2v_{GS1} > v_{GS2}vGS1​>vGS2​, iD1>iD2i_{D1} > i_{D2}iD1​>iD2​, and vD1<vD2v_{D1} < v_{D2}vD1​<vD2​; thus (vD2−vD1)(v_{D2}-v_{D1})(vD2​−vD1​) will be positive.
    • With vidv_{id}vid​ negative: vGS1<vGS2v_{GS1} < v_{GS2}vGS1​<vGS2​, iD1<iD2i_{D1} < i_{D2}iD1​<iD2​, and vD1>vD2v_{D1} > v_{D2}vD1​>vD2​; thus (vD2−vD1)(v_{D2}-v_{D1})(vD2​−vD1​) will be negative.

Large Signal Operation

All we need to know about MOSFET diff pair large-signal operation is that nothing is linear:

We therefore need to bias VOVV_{OV}VOV​ so that small signal would experience linearity.

Small Signal Operation

By convention, the differential input signal vidv_{id}vid​ is applied in a complementary (or balanced manner):

{vG1=VCM+12vidvG2=VCM−12vid\begin{cases} v_{G1}=V_{CM} + \frac{1}{2} v_{id}\\ v_{G2} = V_{CM} - \frac{1}{2} v_{id} \end{cases} {vG1​=VCM​+21​vid​vG2​=VCM​−21​vid​​

Observe that the amplifier output can be taken either between one of the drains and ground, or between the two drains. In the first case, the resulting single-ended outputs vo1v_{o1}vo1​ or vo2v_{o2}vo2​ will be riding on top of the dc voltages at the drain. This will not be the case when output is taken between the two drains; the resulting differential output vodv_{od}vod​ is entirely a single component. (There are other significant advantages to taking the output voltage differentially.)

From the symmetry of the circuit and because of the balanced mnner in which vidv_{id}vid​ is applied, we observe that the signal voltage at the joint source connection must be zero, acting as a virtual ground.

We now compute the gain:

If the output is taken differentially, the gain becomes

Ad=vodvid=vo2−vo1vid=gmRDA_d = \frac{v_{od}}{v_{id}} = \frac{v_{o2}-v_{o1}}{v_{id}} = g_m R_D Ad​=vid​vod​​=vid​vo2​−vo1​​=gm​RD​

If the ouput is taken from half-circuit, we perform half-circuit analysis and obtain the gain to be

Ad=gm(RD∥ro)A_d = g_m (R_D \parallel r_o) Ad​=gm​(RD​∥ro​)

Diff Amp with Current-Source Loads

To obtain a higher gain, the passive resistances RDR_DRD​ can be replaced with current sources (implemented using PMOS transistors). The differential voltage gain AdA_dAd​ can be found from the differential half-circuit as:

Ad≡vodvid=gm1(ro1∥ro3)A_d\equiv \frac{v_{od}}{v_{id}}=g_{m1}(r_{o1} \parallel r_{o3}) Ad​≡vid​vod​​=gm1​(ro1​∥ro3​)

Common-Mode Rejection

Common-Mode Rejection Ratio (CMRR):

CMRR≡∣Ad∣∣Acm∣\textrm{CMRR}\equiv \frac{|A_d|}{|A_{cm}|} CMRR≡∣Acm​∣∣Ad​∣​

  • common-mode gain AcmA_{cm}Acm​
  • differential gain AdA_dAd​

  • The MOS differential amplifier bias-current source output resistance is RSSR_{SS}RSS​.
  • The common-mode dc voltage at both input is defined by VCMV_{CM}VCM​.
  • The incremental signal applied to both input is vicmv_{icm}vicm​.

Our objective is to find how much of vicmv_{icm}vicm​ makes its way to the output of the amplifier.

Effect of RDR_DRD​ mismatch:

Acm=vodvicm=−ΔRD2RSSA_{cm} = \frac{v_{od}}{v_{icm}} = -\frac{\Delta R_D}{2 R_{SS}} Acm​=vicm​vod​​=−2RSS​ΔRD​​

CMRR=(2gmRSS)/(ΔRDRD)\textrm{CMRR} = (2 g_m R_{SS})\left/ \left( \frac{\Delta R_D}{R_D}\right)\right. CMRR=(2gm​RSS​)/(RD​ΔRD​​)

To obtain a high CMRR, we should utilize a bias current source with a high output resistance RSSR_{SS}RSS​, and we should strive to obtain a high degree of matching between the drain resistance.

Effect of gmg_mgm​ mismatch:

Acm≈(RD2RSS)(Δgmgm)A_{cm} \approx \left(\frac{R_D}{2R_{SS}}\right) \left(\frac{\Delta g_m}{g_m}\right) Acm​≈(2RSS​RD​​)(gm​Δgm​​)

CMRR=(2gmRSS)/(Δgmgm)\textrm{CMRR} = (2g_m R_{SS})\left/ \left(\frac{\Delta g_m}{g_m}\right)\right. CMRR=(2gm​RSS​)/(gm​Δgm​​)

To keep CMRR high, we have to use a biasing current source with high output resistance RSSR_{SS}RSS​ and strive to maintain a high degree of matching between Q1Q_1Q1​ and Q2Q_2Q2​.

Note that the above analysis is done on the assumption that the output of the differential amplifier is taken differentially. CMRR will reduce dramatically if we take the output single-endedly.

DC Offset

When we ground both inputs, if the two sides of the diff pair were perfectly matched, then current III would split equally between the two transistors, and VOV_OVO​ would be zero. However, practical circuits exhibit mismatches that result in DC output voltage VOV_OVO​ even with both inputs grounded. We call VOV_OVO​ the ouput dc offset voltage VOV_OVO​. We obtain the input offset voltage VOSV_{OS}VOS​

VOS=VO/AdV_{OS} = V_O / A_d VOS​=VO​/Ad​

You just need to know that it exists, lol.

Diff Amp with Current-Mirror Load

The differential amplifier with differential output has 3 major advantages:

  1. Maximize CMRR.
  2. Decrease input offset voltage.
  3. Increase the differential gain by a factor of 2.

The amplifier is differential in, differential out. At some point, we need to convert the signal from differential to single-ended.

The most basic approach for differential-to-single-ended conversion is illustrated below. The obvious drawback is that we lose a factor of 2 in gain for wasting the drain signal current of Q1Q_1Q1​.

We have small signal

(id)1=i=vidgm/2(i_d)_1= i =v_{id}g_m/2 (id​)1​=i=vid​gm​/2

Observe that at the output node we have 2i2i2i due to differential input as a result of the current-mirror action. This provides a factor of 2 in the gain. In the absence of a load resistance, the output voltage is determined by the output current 2i2i2i and the output resistance of the circuit.

Now to analyze the circuit, The short-circuit transconductance of current-mirror diff amp is

Gm=gm1,2G_m = g_{m1,2} Gm​=gm1,2​

The output resistance is:

Ro=(ro2∥ro4)R_o = (r_{o2}\parallel r_{o4}) Ro​=(ro2​∥ro4​)

The open-circuit differential voltage gain is

Ad≡vovid=GmRo=gm1,2(ro2∥ro4)A_d \equiv \frac{v_o}{v_{id}} = G_m R_o = g_{m1,2} (r_{o2}\parallel r_{o4}) Ad​≡vid​vo​​=Gm​Ro​=gm1,2​(ro2​∥ro4​)

The common-mode rejection ratio is:

CMRR=∣Ad∣∣Acm∣=[gm(ro2∥ro4)][2gm3RSS]\textrm{CMRR} = \frac{|A_d|}{|A_{cm}|} = [g_m (r_{o2}\parallel r_{o4})][2 g_{m3} R_{SS}] CMRR=∣Acm​∣∣Ad​∣​=[gm​(ro2​∥ro4​)][2gm3​RSS​]

Amplifier Frequency Response

There is a frequency band in which the magnitude of gain of a common-source amplifier remains almost constant. This band is called midband.

The amplifier bandwidth aka 3dB bandwith is defined as

BW=fH−fL≈fH(∵fL≪fH)BW=f_H-f_L \approx f_H\qquad(\because f_L\ll f_H) BW=fH​−fL​≈fH​(∵fL​≪fH​)

Bypass Capacitor and Coupling Capacitor

Coupling Capacitor CCC_CCC​:

  • Acts as a short circuit at all signal frequencies of interest while blocking dc.
  • Usually used to connect amplifiers between stages. Note that coupling capacitor is only required when we're doing resistor biasing, which is an obsolete technique. For current-mirror biased circuits, we con't need coupling capacitors in between stages.

Bypass Capacitor: aka signal ground, ac ground

  • Connect directly from output to ground.
  • Signal current passes is shorted to ground via bypass capacitor, bypassing the output resistance.

Dominant Pole: a pole directly responsible for the lower corner frequency fLf_LfL​ of the passband.

Internal Capacitive Effects of MOSFET

{Cgs=CoxW(23L+LovW)Cgd=CoxWLov\begin{cases} C_{gs} = C_{ox}W \left(\frac{2}{3} L + L_{ov}W\right)\\ C_{gd} = C_{ox} WL_{ov} \end{cases} {Cgs​=Cox​W(32​L+Lov​W)Cgd​=Cox​WLov​​

Where CoxC_{ox}Cox​ si the gate capacitance per unit gate area. There are 2 small capacitances resulting from the overlap of the gate with the source region (aka source diffusion) and drain region (aka drain diffusion). Each of these overlaps have a length LovL_{ov}Lov​

High-Frequency MOSFET Model

We only need to memorize the simplified hybrid-π\piπ model shown in the middle.

MOSFET Unity-Gain Frequency

The unity-gain freqeuncy aka transition frequency (which gives rise to the subscript TTT) is defined as the frequency at which the short-circuit current gain of the common-source configuration becomes unity.

Using the hybrid-pipipi model to perform the analysis, we pump in an input current Ii\mathbf{I}_iIi​ at gate and measure the output current Io\mathbf{I}_oIo​ at the drain (shorting from drain to ground), we arrive at

IoIi=gms(Cgs+Cgd)\frac{\mathbf{I}_o}{\mathbf{I}_i} = \frac{g_m}{s(C_{gs}+C_{gd})} Ii​Io​​=s(Cgs​+Cgd​)gm​​

The gain becomes unity at the frequency

ωT=gmCgs+Cgd\omega_T= \frac{g_m}{C_{gs}+ C_{gd}} ωT​=Cgs​+Cgd​gm​​

fT=gm2π(Cgs+Cgd)f_T =\frac{g_m}{2\pi(C_{gs}+ C_{gd})} fT​=2π(Cgs​+Cgd​)gm​​

Observe that:

  • fTf_TfT​ is proportional to gmg_mgm​, which determines the midband gain
  • fTf_TfT​ is inversely proportional to the MOSFET internal capacitances, which limit the amplifier bandwidth

Overall, the higher the value of fTf_TfT​ , the more effective the MOSFET becomes as an amplifier.

Miller's Theorem

Miller's theorem is a technique for replacing bridging capacitance by an equivalent input capacitance.

Consider the situation depicted below. We have two isolated circuit nodes 1 and 2, between which an impedance ZZZ is connected.

It is assumed that somehow it has been determined that the voltage at node 2 is related to that at node 1 by

V2=KV1V_2 = K V_1 V2​=KV1​

In typical situations, KKK is a gain factor that can be positive or negative and has a magnitude usually larger than unity.

Miller's theorem states that impedance ZZZ can be replaced by two impedances: Z1Z_1Z1​ connected between node 1 and ground, and Z2Z_2Z2​ connected between node 2 and ground, where

{Z1=Z/(1−K)Z2=Z/(1−1K)\begin{cases} Z_1 = Z/(1-K)\\ \displaystyle Z_2 = Z/ \left( 1-\frac{1}{K} \right) \end{cases} ⎩⎨⎧​Z1​=Z/(1−K)Z2​=Z/(1−K1​)​

To prove Miller's theorem, we derive expression for currents I1,I2I_1, I_2I1​,I2​:

{I1=V1Z1=V1−KV1Z=II2=0−V2Z2=V1−KV1Z=I\begin{cases} \displaystyle I_1 = \frac{V_1}{Z_1} = \frac{V_1-KV_1}{Z} & = I\\ \displaystyle I_2 = \frac{0-V_2}{Z_2} = \frac{V_1-K V_1}{Z} &=I \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​I1​=Z1​V1​​=ZV1​−KV1​​I2​=Z2​0−V2​​=ZV1​−KV1​​​=I=I​

High-Frequency Response of CS Amplifier

Consider a basic CS amplifier high-frequency model:

We apply open circuit time constant methods

τlp=CgsRgs+CgdRgd+CLRCL=[Cgs+Cgd(1+gmRL′)]Rsig′+(Cgd+CL)RL′\begin{aligned} \tau_{lp} &= C_{gs}R_{gs}+C_{gd}R_{gd}+C_L R_{C_L}\\ &= [C_{gs}+ C_{gd}(1+g_m R_L')] R_{sig}' +(C_{gd} + C_L) R_L' \end{aligned} τlp​​=Cgs​Rgs​+Cgd​Rgd​+CL​RCL​​=[Cgs​+Cgd​(1+gm​RL′​)]Rsig′​+(Cgd​+CL​)RL′​​

  • Note that the first term is CinRsig′C_{in} R_{sig}'Cin​Rsig′​ at the input node, where CinC_{in}Cin​ is dominated by the Miller capacitance Cgd(1+gmRL′)C_{gd}(1+g_m R_L')Cgd​(1+gm​RL′​).
  • The method of open-circuit time constant also provides the second term, which results from the interaction of (Cgd+CL)(C_{gd}+C_L)(Cgd​+CL​) with RL′R_L'RL′​ at the output node.

Consider a current-mirror load Common-Source Amplifier:

The open-circuit midband gain AMA_MAM​ can be derived:

(AM)o=−gm1⋅(ro1∥ro2)(A_M)_o= - g_{m1}\cdot (r_{o1}\parallel r_{o2}) (AM​)o​=−gm1​⋅(ro1​∥ro2​)

Now we do open-circuit time constant analysis:

τlp=Cgs1Rgs1+Cgd1Rgd1+Cgd2Rds1\tau_{lp}= C_{gs1} R_{gs1} + C_{gd1} R_{gd1} + C_{gd2} R_{ds1} τlp​=Cgs1​Rgs1​+Cgd1​Rgd1​+Cgd2​Rds1​

{Rgs1=RsigRgd1=(1+gm1RL′)Rsig+RL′Rds1=RL′\begin{cases} R_{gs1} = R_{sig}\\ R_{gd1} = (1+g_{m1} R_L') R_{sig} + R_L'\\ R_{ds1} = R_L' \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​Rgs1​=Rsig​Rgd1​=(1+gm1​RL′​)Rsig​+RL′​Rds1​=RL′​​

A few notes:

  • Rgs1R_{gs1}Rgs1​ is the resistance seen by the capacitor Cgs1C_{gs1}Cgs1​
  • Rds1R_{ds1}Rds1​ is the resistance seen from the drain-to-source terminal
  • The reason CgsC_{gs}Cgs​ is not considered is simply that both of its terminals are grounded, it therefore sees zero resistance.

High-Frequency Response of the Common-Gate

It's important to note that at each of the 3 capacitences in the CG high-frequency model has a grounded node. Therefore none of the capacitances in the circuit undergoes the Miller multiplication effect observed in the CS stage. It follows that the CG circuit c an be designed to have a much wider bandwidth than that of the CS circuit, especially when RsigR_{sig}Rsig​ is large.

Applying the open-circuit time-constant methods:

τgs=Cgs(Rsig∥Rin)τgd=(CL+Cgd)(RL∥Ro)\tau_{gs} = C_{gs}\left(R_{sig}\parallel R_{in}\right) \qquad \tau_{gd}=\left(C_L+C_{gd}\right) (R_L\parallel R_o) τgs​=Cgs​(Rsig​∥Rin​)τgd​=(CL​+Cgd​)(RL​∥Ro​)

where

Rin=ro+RL1+gmro≈ro+RLgmroRo=ro+Rsig+gmroRsigR_{in} = \frac{r_o + R_L}{1+g_m r_o}\approx \frac{r_o + R_L}{g_m r_o} \qquad R_o= r_o+R_{sig} + g_m r_o R_{sig}Rin​=1+gm​ro​ro​+RL​​≈gm​ro​ro​+RL​​Ro​=ro​+Rsig​+gm​ro​Rsig​

τH=τgs+τgd\tau_H = \tau_{gs} + \tau_{gd} τH​=τgs​+τgd​

Note that the τH\tau_HτH​ of CG amplifier is much lower than that of a CS amplifier. Therefore, a properly designed CG circuit can have a wide bandwidth.

High-Frequency Response of the MOS Cascode Amplifier

Using open-circuit time constants method, we obtain

τH=Cgs1Rsig+Cgd1[(1+gm1 Rd1)Rsig+Rd1]+(Cdb1+Cgs2)Rd1+(CL+Cgd2)(RL∥Ro)=Rsig[Cgs1+Cgd1(1+gm1Rd1)]+Rd1(Cgd1+Cdb1+Cgs2)+(RL∥Ro)(CL+Cgd2)\begin{aligned} \tau_H &= C_{gs1} R_{sig} + C_{gd1}[(1+g_{m1}\ R_{d1}) R_{sig} + R_{d1}]\\ &\qquad+ (C_{db1} + C_{gs2}) R_{d1} + (C_L + C_{gd2})(R_L\parallel R_o)\\ &= R_{sig} [C_{gs1} + C_{gd1} (1+g_{m1} R_{d1})] + R_{d1}(C_{gd1} + C_{db1} + C_{gs2})\\ &\qquad+(R_L\parallel R_o)(C_L + C_{gd2}) \end{aligned} τH​​=Cgs1​Rsig​+Cgd1​[(1+gm1​ Rd1​)Rsig​+Rd1​]+(Cdb1​+Cgs2​)Rd1​+(CL​+Cgd2​)(RL​∥Ro​)=Rsig​[Cgs1​+Cgd1​(1+gm1​Rd1​)]+Rd1​(Cgd1​+Cdb1​+Cgs2​)+(RL​∥Ro​)(CL​+Cgd2​)​

Here we note that the first term arises at the input node (note the Miller effect), the second term at the middle node, namely (D1,s2)(D_1, s_2)(D1​,s2​), and the third term at the output node.

In the case of large RsigR_{sig}Rsig​, the first term can dominate. Note, however, that

Rd1=ro1∥Rin2=ro1∥ro2+RLgm2ro2R_{d1}=r_{o1}\parallel R_{in2} = r_{o1}\parallel \frac{r_{o2} + R_L}{g_{m2} r_{o2}} Rd1​=ro1​∥Rin2​=ro1​∥gm2​ro2​ro2​+RL​​

Even after the miller effect, Cgd1(1+gm1Rd1)C_{gd1}(1+g_{m1} R_{d1})Cgd1​(1+gm1​Rd1​) is still smaller than its counter part in CS amplifier, meaning cascode amplifier can achieve much greater bandwidth. To extend the bandwidth, we have to lower RLR_LRL​ to the order of ror_oro​. This in turn lowers rd1r_{d1}rd1​ and renders the Miller effect insignificant. The trade off of extended bandwidth is that the dc gain will be the same as (or a little higher than) that achieved in a CS amplifier (because of the lowered load resistance).

In the case when RsigR_{sig}Rsig​ is small, the Miller effect in Q1Q_1Q1​ will not be of concern. A large value of RLR_LRL​ (on the order of A0roA_0 r_oA0​ro​) can then be used to realize the large dc gain [on the order of (A0)2(A_0)^2(A0​)2] possible with this cascode amplifier. In this case the third term of τH\tau_HτH​ will usually dominate (assume the middle term is much smaller than the third term), if we set RsigR_{sig}Rsig​ to 0

τH≈(CL+Cgd2)(RL∥Ro)\tau_H\approx (C_L + C_{gd2})(R_L \parallel R_o) τH​≈(CL​+Cgd2​)(RL​∥Ro​)

which is of the same form for the CS amplifier with Rsig=0R_{sig} = 0Rsig​=0. Note however, (RL∥Ro)(R_L\parallel R_o)(RL​∥Ro​) is larger than RL′R_L'RL′​ by a factor of about A0A_0A0​. Thus the bandwidth of the cascode will be lower than that of the CS amplifier by the same factor A0A_0A0​.

The MOS cascode amplifier is a versatile circuit that can be designed to provide either higher dc gain, larger bandwidth, or a combination of both than the CS amplifier.

High-Frequency Response of the Source Follower

Source Follower find application as the output stage of a multistage amplifier and voltage buffer. These voltage followers also have another important advantage - a wide bandwidth.

The source follower has two high-frequency poles that can be close to each other on the negative real axis of the sss plane. Furthermore, in many cases, the poles can become complex. As a result, we cannot use the method of open-circuit time constants to determine bandwidth except in special circumstances. Our approach is to determine the transfer function Vo/VsigV_o/V_{sig}Vo​/Vsig​ and then use it to determine fHf_HfH​.

Whatever, here is the current-mirror loaded configuration using open-circuit time constant methods:

τH=Cgd1Rsig+(Cgs1)Rgs1+(Cgd2+Cdb2+Csb1+CL)Rout≈Cgd1Rsig\tau_H = C_{gd1} R_{sig} + (C_{gs1}) R_{gs1} + (C_{gd2}+C_{db2} + C_{sb1} + C_L) R_{out} \approx C_{gd1} R_{sig} τH​=Cgd1​Rsig​+(Cgs1​)Rgs1​+(Cgd2​+Cdb2​+Csb1​+CL​)Rout​≈Cgd1​Rsig​

where

Rout=1gm1+gmb1∥ro1∥ro2∥RL≈1gm1+gmb1RL′=ro1∥ro2∥RLRgs1=Rsig+RL′1+(gm1+gmb1)RL′\begin{aligned} R_{out} &= \frac{1}{g_{m1} + g_{mb1}} \parallel r_{o1}\parallel r_{o2} \parallel R_L \approx \frac{1}{g_{m1} + g_{mb1}}\\ R_L' &= r_{o1}\parallel r_{o2}\parallel R_L\\ R_{gs1} &= \frac{R_{sig} + R_L'}{1+(g_{m1} + g_{mb1})R_L'} \end{aligned} Rout​RL′​Rgs1​​=gm1​+gmb1​1​∥ro1​∥ro2​∥RL​≈gm1​+gmb1​1​=ro1​∥ro2​∥RL​=1+(gm1​+gmb1​)RL′​Rsig​+RL′​​​

High-Frequency Response of Differential Amplifier

Consider the current-mirror-loaded MOS amplifier

  • CmC_mCm​: the total capacitance at the input node of the current mirror
  • CLC_LCL​: the total capacitance at the output node.

{Cm=Cgd1+Cdb1+Cdb3+Cgs3+Cgs4CL=Cgd2+Cdb2+Cgd4+Cdb4+Cx\begin{cases} C_m = C_{gd1} + C_{db1} + C_{db3} + C_{gs3} + C_{gs4}\\ C_L = C_{gd2} + C_{db2} + C_{gd4} + C_{db4} + C_{x} \end{cases} {Cm​=Cgd1​+Cdb1​+Cdb3​+Cgs3​+Cgs4​CL​=Cgd2​+Cdb2​+Cgd4​+Cdb4​+Cx​​

Vo=Io(Ro∥1sCL)=GmVidRo1+sCLRo\begin{aligned} V_o &= I_o \left( R_o \parallel \frac{1}{sC_L} \right)\\ &=G_m V_{id} \frac{R_o}{1+sC_L R_o} \end{aligned} Vo​​=Io​(Ro​∥sCL​1​)=Gm​Vid​1+sCL​Ro​Ro​​​

Av=VoVid=(gmRo)(1+sCm2gm31+sCmgm3)(11+sCLRo)A_v = \frac{V_o}{V_{id}} =(g_m R_o) \left(\frac{\displaystyle 1+s\frac{C_m}{2 g_{m3}}}{\displaystyle 1+s\frac{C_m}{g_{m3}}}\right)\left(\frac{1}{1+sC_L R_o}\right) Av​=Vid​Vo​​=(gm​Ro​)⎝⎜⎜⎛​1+sgm3​Cm​​1+s2gm3​Cm​​​⎠⎟⎟⎞​(1+sCL​Ro​1​)

Now we discuss the consequences. In general CmC_mCm​ and CLC_LCL​ dominate the frequency response.

ωp1=1CLRo,ωp2=gm3Cm\omega_{p1} = \frac{1}{C_L R_o},\qquad\omega_{p2}=\frac{g_{m3}}{C_m} ωp1​=CL​Ro​1​,ωp2​=Cm​gm3​​

We also have a zero associated with the Q3,Q4Q_3, Q_4Q3​,Q4​ current mirror

ωz=2gm3Cm\omega_{z} = \frac{2 g_{m3}}{C_m} ωz​=Cm​2gm3​​

Recall that the transistor unit current gain frequency is ft=gm2π(Cgs+Cgd)\displaystyle f_t=\frac{g_m}{2\pi (C_{gs} + C_{gd})}ft​=2π(Cgs​+Cgd​)gm​​ which is very close to fzf_zfz​. This zero lifts the opamp's phase as it approaches ftf_tft​ to avoid unwanted positive feedback.

Output Stages

An important function of the output stage is to provide the amplifier with a low output resistance so that it can deliver the output signal to the load without loss of gain. Since the output stage is the final stage of the amplifier, it usually deals with relatively large signals. Thus the small-signal approximations and models either are not applicable or must be used with care.

The most challenging requirement in the design of an output stage is for it to deliver the required amount of power to the load in an efficient manner. This implies that the power dissipated in the output-stage transistors must be as low as possible. There are various output-stage configurations employed in amplifiers that handle both low and high power. In this context, "high power" generally means greater than 1W.

A power amplifier is simply an amplifier with a high-power output stage.

Output Stage Parameters

Linearity remains a very important requirement. A measurement of goodness of the output stage is the total harmonic distortion (THD) it introduces. This is the rms value of the harmonic components of the output signal (Fourier transform?), excluding the fundamental, expressed as a percentage of the rms of the fundamental.

THD=∑i=2∞(rms power of harmonics)irms power of fundamental\textrm{THD} =\frac{\displaystyle \sum_{i=2}^\infty \textrm{(rms power of harmonics)}_i}{\textrm{rms power of fundamental}} THD=rms power of fundamentali=2∑∞​(rms power of harmonics)i​​

The power-conversion efficiency of an output stage is defined as

η=PLPS≡Load PowerSupply Power\eta = \frac{P_L}{P_S}\equiv \frac{\textrm{Load Power}}{\textrm{Supply Power}} η=PS​PL​​≡Supply PowerLoad Power​

Basic Classifications

Output stages are classified according to the collector-current waveform that results when an input signal is applied.

  • The class A stage is biased at current ICI_CIC​ that is greater than the amplitude of the signal current I^c\hat I_cI^c​. Thus the transistor in class A stage conducts for the entire cycle of the input signal; that is, the conduction angle is 360deg⁡360 \deg360deg.
  • The class B stage is biased at zero dc current. Thus a transistor in class BBB stage conducts for only half the cycle of the input sine wave, resulting in a conduction angle of 180deg⁡180 \deg180deg. (The negative halves of the sinusoid will be supplied by another transistor that also operates in the class B mode and conducts during the alternate half-cycles.)
  • The class AB stage biases the transistor at a nonzero dc current much smaller than the peak current of the sine wave signal. As a result, the transistor conducts for an interval slightly greater than half a cycle. The resulting conduction angle is in the range (180,360)deg⁡(180, 360)\deg(180,360)deg. The class AB stage has another transistor that conducts for an interval slightly greater than that of the negative half-cycle, and the currents from the two transistors are combined in the load. It follows that during the intervals near the zero crossings of the input sinusoid, both transistors conduct.

Class A Output Stage

Because of its low output resistance, the emitter follower is the most popular class A output stage. We have already known the small-signal operation of the emitter follower, now we consider its large-signal operation.

  • Emitter current iE1=I+iLi_{E1} = I + i_LiE1​=I+iL​, the bias current III must be greater than the largest negative load current, otherwise Q1Q_1Q1​ cuts off.
  • vO=vI−vBE1v_O = v_I - v_{BE1}vO​=vI​−vBE1​, where vBE1v_{BE1}vBE1​ depends on emitter current iE1i_{E1}iE1​ and on the load current iLi_LiL​. There is going to be a small change in vBE1v_{BE1}vBE1​, but the large signal voltage characteristic is largely linear. In other words, since BJT's iCi_CiC​-vBEv_{BE}vBE​ characteristic is exponential (unlike MOSFET's quadratic), we practically ignore the change in vBE1v_{BE1}vBE1​. Note that this is also the reason why MOSFET has superior output stage characteristic than MOSFET.
  • Upper output limit: vOmax=VCC−VCE1satv_{Omax}=V_{CC} - V_{CE1sat}vOmax​=VCC​−VCE1sat​
  • Lower output limit: vOmin=−IRLv_{Omin} = -IR_LvOmin​=−IRL​ or −VCC+VCE2sat-V_{CC} + V_{CE2sat}−VCC​+VCE2sat​ whichever is higher.
  • The bias current must be greater than the absolute lowest possible output voltage: I≥∣−VCC+VCE2sat∣RL\displaystyle I\ge \frac{|-V_{CC} + V_{CE2sat}|}{R_L}I≥RL​∣−VCC​+VCE2sat​∣​

Under the condition I=VCC/RLI=V_{CC}/R_LI=VCC​/RL​, and ignoring the transistor saturation voltage, we have the signal waveform.

Note the instantaneous power dissipation in Q1Q_1Q1​ is defined as pD1≡vCE1ic1p_{D1}\equiv v_{CE1} i_{c1}pD1​≡vCE1​ic1​.

In the event of short--circuit, a very large current may flow through Q1Q_1Q1​, and if the short-circuit condition persists, the resulting large power dissipation in Q1Q_1Q1​ can raise its junction temperature beyond maximum allowed, causing permanent damage. Normally the output stages are equipped with short-circuit protection.

Now we compute the power-conversion efficiency. Assume the output voltage is a sinusoid with the peak value V^o\hat{V}_oV^o​, the average load power is

PL=(V^o/2)2RL=12V^o2RLP_L = \frac{(\hat{V}_o/\sqrt{2})^2}{R_L}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\hat{V}_o^2}{R_L} PL​=RL​(V^o​/2​)2​=21​RL​V^o2​​

The average supply power is

PS=2VCCIP_S = 2 V_{CC} I PS​=2VCC​I

The power efficiency is

η≡PLPS=14(V^oIRL)(V^oVCC)\eta\equiv \frac{P_L}{P_S}=\frac{1}{4} \left( \frac{\hat{V}_o}{IR_L} \right)\left( \frac{\hat{V}_o}{V_{CC}} \right) η≡PS​PL​​=41​(IRL​V^o​​)(VCC​V^o​​)

Since V^o≤VCC\hat{V}_o \le V{CC}V^o​≤VCC, V^o≤IRL\hat{V}_o\le IR_LV^o​≤IRL​, the maximum efficiency is obtained when V^o=VCC=IRL\hat{V}_o = V_{CC} = IR_LV^o​=VCC​=IRL​ which is 25%25\%25%.

Note that the class A output stage is rarely used in high-power application (>1 W)(>1\ W)(>1 W). In practice the output voltage swing is limited to lower values to avoid transistor saturation adn associated nonlinear distortion. Thus the efficiency achieved in practice is usually in the 10-20 percent range.

Class B Output Stage

When the input voltage vIv_IvI​ is zero, both trnasistors are cut off and the output voltage vOv_OvO​ is zero. As vIv_IvI​ exceeds VtV_tVt​, QNQ_NQN​ conducts and operates as an emitter follower (vO=vI−vBENv_O=v_I - v_{BEN}vO​=vI​−vBEN​). Meanwhile, the emitter-base junction of QPQ_PQP​ will be reverse-biased and QPQ_PQP​ will be cut off.

Similarly, QPQ_PQP​ turns on when the input goes negative by more than VtV_tVt​. The class B output stage operates in a push-pull fashion. QNQ_NQN​ pushes the source current into the load when vIv_IvI​ is positive, QPQ_PQP​ pulls the sink current from the load when vIv_IvI​ is negative.

There exists a range of vIv_IvI​ centered around zero when both transistors are cut off and vOv_OvO​ is zero. This dead band results in crossover distortion.

The power efficiency for a class B output stage ranges from 50% to 78.5%.

Class AB Output Stage

Crossover distortion can virtually be eliminated by biasing the complementary output transistors at a small non-zero current.

Short-Circuit Protection

When short circuit occurs:

  1. Large current flow through Q1Q_1Q1​, causing voltage drop across RE1R_{E1}RE1​.
  2. Q5Q_5Q5​ turns on, robbing Q1Q_1Q1​ of its base drive, the current through Q1Q_1Q1​ will thus be reduced to a safe operating level.

CMOS Inverter

General Structure of CMOS Logic

A CMOS logic circuit is in effect an extension of the CMOS inverter. The inverter consists of an NMOS pull-down transistor and a PMOS pull-up transistor. The CMOS logic gate consists of two networks: the pull-down network (PDN) using NMOS, and the pull-up network (PUN) using PMOS.

Finding Input/Output Resistance from Terminal

  1. Turn off all signals
  2. Turn off all independent sources
  3. Apply test voltage vxv_xvx​
  4. Measure current ixi_xix​

Five Tau Rule

Transition from a steady state to another steady state lasts only for five τ\tauτ seconds. For example, a switching off source from an R-C circuit and thus the change in the current amount flowing in the R-C circuit from a certain level to zero takes five τ\tauτ seconds.

To see why 5τ5\tau5τ, we copy from wikipedia: suppose V(t)=V0e−t/τV(t)=V_0 e^{-t/\tau}V(t)=V0​e−t/τ is an exponential decay response with time constant τ\tauτ:

{t=0V=V0e0=V0t=τV=V0e01≈0.37V0t=5τV=V0e−5≈0.0067V0\begin{cases} t=0 & V=V_0 e^0 = V_0\\ t=\tau & V=V_0 e^{01} \approx 0.37 V_0\\ t = 5\tau & V=V_0 e^{-5} \approx 0.0067 V_0 \end{cases} ⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​t=0t=τt=5τ​V=V0​e0=V0​V=V0​e01≈0.37V0​V=V0​e−5≈0.0067V0​​

Determining Approximate Corner Frequency

Capacitors are responsible for the corner frequency. We use dominant poles to estimate low and high corner frequencies of midband. We only worry about those capacitors in the path from input to ground and from input to output.

Low Frequency: Short-Circuit Time Constants Method

When we wish to find high-pass frequency fhpf_{hp}fhp​ of a complex network, we use this method.

Although this method is predicated on the assumption that one of the poles is dominant, the result estimate is usually ver good even if this assumption is not strictly valid.

  1. Set the input signal Vsig=0V_{sig}=0Vsig​=0.
  2. Consider the capcitors one at a time. While considering capacitor CiC_iCi​:
    • set all other capacitors to infinite values (i.e. replace them with short circuits - hence the name of the method)
    • find the total resistance RiR_iRi​ seen by CiC_iCi​. This can be determined either by inspection or by replacing CiC_iCi​ wiht a voltage source VxV_xVx​ and finding the current IxI_xIx​ drawn from VxV_xVx​; Ri=Vx/IxR_i = V_x / I_xRi​=Vx​/Ix​.
  3. Compute the 3 dB frequency using fL≈∑i=1n1CiRi\displaystyle f_L \approx \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{C_i R_i}fL​≈i=1∑n​Ci​Ri​1​ where nnn is the total number of capacitors. Note that τi=CiRi\tau_i = C_i R_iτi​=Ci​Ri​

Note that the lower the value of time constant associated with a particular capacitor, the greater the contribution of this capacitor to fLf_LfL​.

High Frequency: Open-Circuit Time Constants Method

when we wish to find low-pass frequency flpf_{lp}flp​ of a complex network, we use this method.

  1. Set input signal Vsig=0V_{sig}=0Vsig​=0
  2. Consider the capacitors one at a time. While considering capacitor CiC_iCi​:
    • set all other capacitors to open circuit
    • find total resistance RiR_iRi​ seen by CiC_iCi​.
  3. Compute 3 dB frequency using τlp≈∑i=1nτi\displaystyle \tau_{lp}\approx \sum_{i=1}^n \tau_iτlp​≈i=1∑n​τi​

The method of open-circuit time constants reveals the relative contribution of the various capacitances tothe determination fo the amplifier bandwidth fHf_HfH​. The higher the time constant, the lower the amplifier bandwidth is.

High Frequency Dominant Pole

Consider the transfer function

H(s)=AMFH(s)H(s)=A_M F_H(s) H(s)=AM​FH​(s)

where

FH(s)=∑i=1n(1+sωZi)∑i=1n(1+sωPi)F_H(s)= \frac{\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n \left(1+\frac{s}{\omega_{Zi}}\right)}{\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n \left(1+\frac{s}{\omega_{Pi}}\right)} FH​(s)=i=1∑n​(1+ωPi​s​)i=1∑n​(1+ωZi​s​)​

By definition, at ω=ωH\omega= \omega_Hω=ωH​, ∣FH∣2=1/2|F_H|^2=1/2∣FH​∣2=1/2, thus

12=∑i=1n(1+ωH2ωZi2)∑i=1n(1+ωH2ωPi2)=1+ωH2∑i=1n(1ωZi2)+ωH2n∏k=1nωZk21+ωH2∑i=1n(1ωPi2)+ωH2n∏k=1nωPk2\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} &= \frac{\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n \left(1+\frac{\omega_H^2}{\omega_{Zi}^2}\right)}{\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n \left(1+\frac{\omega_H^2}{\omega_{Pi}^2}\right)} &= \frac{ \displaystyle 1+\omega_H^2\sum_{i=1}^n \left( \frac{1}{\omega_{Zi}^2} \right) + \frac{\omega_H^{2n}}{\displaystyle \prod_{k=1}^n \omega_{Zk}^2} } { \displaystyle 1+\omega_H^2\sum_{i=1}^n \left( \frac{1}{\omega_{Pi}^2} \right) + \frac{\omega_H^{2n}}{\displaystyle \prod_{k=1}^n \omega_{Pk}^2} } \end{aligned} 21​​=i=1∑n​(1+ωPi2​ωH2​​)i=1∑n​(1+ωZi2​ωH2​​)​​=1+ωH2​i=1∑n​(ωPi2​1​)+k=1∏n​ωPk2​ωH2n​​1+ωH2​i=1∑n​(ωZi2​1​)+k=1∏n​ωZk2​ωH2n​​​​

Since ωH\omega_HωH​ is usually smaller than the frequencies of all the poles and zeroes, we may neglect the term containing ωH2n\omega_H^{2n}ωH2n​ and obtain the approximation:

ωH≈1/∑i=1n1ωPi2−2∑i=1n1ωZi2\omega_H\approx 1\left/ \sqrt{ \displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{\omega_{P_i}^2} - 2\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{\omega_{Z_i}^2} } \right. ωH​≈1/i=1∑n​ωPi​2​1​−2i=1∑n​ωZi​2​1​​

Note that if one of the poles, P1P_1P1​ for example, is dominant, then ωP1≪ωPi,ωZj,∀i>1,j>0\omega_{P1}\ll\omega_{P_i}, \omega_{Z_j}, \forall i>1, j>0ωP1​≪ωPi​​,ωZj​​,∀i>1,j>0, and the equation reduces to

ωH≈ωP1\omega_H\approx \omega_{P1} ωH​≈ωP1​

The open-circuit time constants method is an approximation method based on this.

Op Amp Compensation Capacitance

From wikipedia, frequency compensation is a technique used in amplifiers, and especially in amplifiers employing negative feedback. It usually has two primary goals:

  1. To avoid the unintentional creation of positive feedback, which will cause the amplifier to oscillate. In other words, it insures that the op-amp circuits to be stable as opposed to oscillatory.
  2. To control overshoot and ringing in the amplifier's step response.

Consider this 2-stage op amp:

The second stage (CS) typically provides a gain of 50 V/V to 80 V/V. To guarantee that the op amp will operate in stable fashion when negative feedback of various amounts is applied, the open-loop gain is made to roll off with frequency at the uniform rate of -20 dB/decade. This is achieved by introducing a pole at a relatively low frequency and arrange for it to dominate the frequency-response. This pole is implemented using the compensation capacitor CCC_CCC​ is connect between the input and output of the CS cell. CCC_CCC​ (together with a much smaller capacitance Cgd6C_{gd6}Cgd6​) is Miller-multiplied by the gain of the second stage. This boosts the capacitance and provides the required dominant pole.

This compensation capacitor CCC_CCC​ is directly responsible for the slew-rate, but we don't investigate it here.
